Use of United Nations visual identity: The expert notes that the document appears authentic at first glance because it uses the international body's visual identity for official reports.
Lack of existence of Civilian Weapons Co: The expert confirms that while the United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs (UNODA) exists, the Civilian Weapons Confiscation Study Group does not, indicating that the claim is not authentic.
Non: existent identification number: The document's identification number, A/CN.11/L.72, does not exist in the UN's official document database, further suggesting that the claim is false.
Barcode linked to unrelated communicatio: Certain versions of the screenshot feature a barcode that, when searched, is found to be linked to an official October 2012 communication outlining the provisional agenda for a Disarmament Commission session in April 2013. This discrepancy raises doubts about the authenticity of the document shared on social media.
